div.p: NAMESIGNIFIER, an attribute attached to the elements NICKNAME, PSEUDONYM, and SELFCONSTRUCTED (sub-tags of PERSONNAME in the Biography section of entries), is used to distinguish the way such names derive their significance, with values of cryptic, local, and romance, according to whether the name signifies a hidden meaning (for instance, a variant or anagram of the writer’s own name), a geographical location or association, or reference to the romance tradition.

Use cryptic to designate names that are deliberately obscure. Cryptic names mostly have lexical meaning such as A Housewife, A Lover of her Sex, or A Placid Reader. It follows that personal names are not usually cryptic, with the exception of those borrowed from a fictional character (like Portia, or like Henrietta Battier’s calling herself Patt. Pindar, Pat. T.Pindar and similar, with a complex allusion - to the satirist John Wolcot, who wrote as Peter Pindar, and to the ancient poet Pindar, whom Wolcot referenced). The Author of . . . is not a nickname, has occasionally been listed as a pseudonym. (Remember to record this title-page identifier in the WRITING section of the entry under PAUTHORSHIP, using the allusive value.)

Use local when the person is known by a geographic connotation, for example "Julian of Norwich, Ann of Swansea. Use romance in cases where a name is associated with writing romances, or with romantic writing, for example Stella, Fidelia, Rosa Matilda.

div.codeblock: Janet Little wrote as<PSEUDONYM WROTEORPUBLISHEDAS="WrotePublishedAsYes" NAMESIGNIFIER="cryptic"><SOCALLED>The Scotch Milkmaid.</SOCALLED></PSEUDONYM>
Anne Grant<NICKNAME WROTEORPUBLISHEDAS="WrotePublishedAsYes" NAMESIGNIFIER="Local" >of Laggan</NICKNAME> Above is a nickname of Anne Grant of Laggan.
<PSEUDONYM WROTEORPUBLISHEDAS="WrotePublishedAsYes" NAMESIGNIFIER="romance" REG="Astrea">Astrea or Astraea</PSEUDONYM>; this is a pseudonym of Aphra Behn.

div.p: Remember to use this attribute if any of its three values apply to your name. If not, leave blank. Familial nicknames may be cryptic. For example, Sarah Scott was referred to within her family as Pea (from the idea that she and her sister were like two peas in a pod). There are cases where a personal name can take the cryptic attribute. For example, when Henrietta Battier called herself Patt. Pindar, Pat. T.Pindar and similar, it was not that she was pretending to be called Pat, but with a double allusion - she was implying she was a spiritual sister of the famous satirist John Wolcot, who wrote as Peter Pindar (which is in itself an allusion to the ancient poet Pindar). In cases like this, use the cryptic attribute but please explain in a scholar's note the nature and meaning of the name for future readers.
Question: Rebecca West's husband referred to her romantically and affectionately as Rac. Is this a romance nickname?
Answer: No. Romance applies to a specific type of name used in romance writing.
